headline: Best Jambalaya
description: A spicy jambalaya with chicken, andouille sausage, rice and Cajun seasonings that's easy to make in one pot.

video.description: See how to make a spicy jambalaya with chicken and andouille sausage.
video.name: Jambalaya

name: Best Jambalaya
recipeIngredient: 10 ounces andouille sausage, sliced into rounds
1 pound boneless skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1 inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 tablespoon of peanut oil in a large heavy Dutch oven over medium heat. Season the sausage and chicken pieces with Cajun seasoning. Saut√© sausage until browned. Remove with slotted spoon, and set aside.
Add 1 tablespoon peanut oil, and saut√© chicken pieces until lightly browned on all sides. Remove with a slotted spoon, and set aside.
In the same pot, saute onion, bell pepper, celery, and garlic until tender.
Stir in crushed tomatoes, and season with red pepper, black pepper, salt, hot pepper sauce, Worcestershire sauce, and fil√© powder.
Stir in chicken and sausage. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Stir in the rice and chicken broth.
Bring to a boil, reduce heat, and simmer for 20 to 25 minutes, or until liquid is absorbed.

review.reviewBody: Changed it up a little with fire roasted diced tomatoes, crawfish tails and a couple of other things. Will definitely make again!

Excellent recipe. I had to modify slightly with on-hand ingredients, but it was very close. TIP: ALWAYS use uncooked rice with chicken broth, it really elevates the flavor. I used the Ninja pressure cooker and it cooked perfectly in 10 minutes. This recipe has now replaced Zatarian's forever! Thank you.

I have always enjoyed jambalaya but have never made it until today. This recipe gave me a great base. I added a bit to it and it turned out great. We used hot sausage from Costco because that was what was available. I doubled the garlic, crushed red pepper , and hot sauce (our hot sauce is flavourful but medium heat. I used a yellow pepper and red onion. After cooking the sausage I deglazed with red wine and then cooked the chicken. I used a 28 oz can of crushed heirloom tomatoes. The rice started sticking to the bottom of the Dutch oven so I added the remaining amount of a 975 ml container of vegetable broth. I also added about 2 cups of shrimp. I omitted the file powder because it wasn‚Äôt available in my area. I think okra would be a great addition and plan to add that next time.

I‚Äôm giving it a four because too many details are missing. I used a 28oz can of crushed tomatoes. For those asking about the rice, you should actually cook it with a lid for the last 20 mins so that the rice cooks!

Followed the recipe for the most part. Used a little less chicken and added shrimp at the end. (That i seasoned and quick fried separately) Used about 2/3 of a 28 oz can crushed tomatoes. I like it a little spicy so upped the hot sauce. In reading the posts about uncooked rice i made sure to cover the pot with foil and lid to help seal. Just opened once halfway through to stir. (Used jasmine rice) Came out perfect.
Absolutely delicious! I cooked the rice separately with chicken broth instead of water. I also added shrimp and doubled the recipe for guaranteed leftovers. My whole family loves it! ü§§
The flavor is good but the rice never cooked. I was wondering how that was going to work and it didn't! Cook rice first
Excellent - I will make a little bit of adjustments next time but it was great!

Being a pescatarian, I did modify for me: plant-based sausage, cod for chicken, I added shrimp, used a spicy veggie broth, and added a bit more celery and a larger can of crushed tomatoes. I used olive oil. I know that sounds like a lot of modification, but the recipe did really help me along with the rest. And, it turned out DELICIOUS!! I took it to the restaurant where I work and where we were serving Jambalya for Fat Tuesday - knowing I would not be able to eat the restaurant's version. Three employess (including a kitchen manager) tried my dish, and all liked it more than the one we were serving; all three saying mine had much more and better flavor! I really loved it, have plenty of leftovers, and will definately be saving this recipe and using it again!
This was a great recipe! The closest recipe to The Napoleon House in New Orleans!!! I used Uncle Ben‚Äôs rice and didn‚Äôt have a crunch issue. Will definitely make again.

Disclaimer! Not all recipes cater to your preferences. Jambalaya is naturally a spicy dish. The undercooked rice seems to be an oversight. The recipe doesn't state to either leave it uncooked or prepare it beforehand. I followed the others advice and cooked my rice separately. Didn't have chicken broth so I used chicken bouillon and didn't have fil√© powder, so I substituted it with cornstarch (both are thickening agents). Added 2lbs of cooked shrimp as well as increased the crushed tomatoes to 28oz instead. I also increased the spice amount (I eyeballed it, shouldn't take too much more). It was absolutely delicious!
Amazing recipe! Only thing I would change is finding an alternative to File Powder.... No one knows what that is!
Flavor was good, rice was extremely crunchy with this recipe will change the ratio next time

This recipe was excellent I like mine a little on the extra spicy side so I just went a little heavier on the cajun seasoning but BABBBYYYY this was right on the money . I also added some shrimp to it as well! Will definitely be putting this in my rotation.
Husband loves it. I put crawfish in. I'm allergic to shell fish or it would be shrimp üòÇ

I'm making it now; I think the 1T peanut oil isn't enough but that's what I added. I didn't have chicken broth, so I scooped out a bit (well more than that) of "better than bouillon " and added it to the low-salt veggie stock that I had. I've read a few reviews so I'm going to simmer it for about 45 min so the rice can soak up the liquid, and if I have to simmer it longer, well' it's Saturday night. But it smells good!

I‚Äôve tried twice to make this recipe and it has not worked for me. First time was too hot and spicy to eat. Second time, I cut spices down and was better to where I could eat it. Problem both times with rice not cooking even with adding more liquid. No luck with this recipe!

Did not use file powder and substituted canola oil. Enlarged the recipe to use a 28 oz. can of crushed tomatoes, 2# of chicken, 3 stalks celery. Added the rice early after reading the comments on it being undercooked. Added 2# of cooked shrimp. Kept at a low boil to ensure rice was cooked. Wonderful & with a nice zip!

I substituted poblano pepper for the green pepper, also didn't have the diced tomatoes so I used a can of tomato paste. I added shrimp, and made a little shrimp broth from the shrimp shells and added it to the liquid. The rice came out slightly chewy, so I would cook it a little longer next time. Result was crazy good! I will definitely make this again! It's a forgiving recipe, and had nice heat. Excellent!

We loved it- definitely better to cook it altogether with the rice instead of cooking the rice separate. Probably need to turn the temperature down a little for a lower simmer so the liquids don't cook off too fast. And cover the pot!!! Cooked it according to recipe but didn't use file powder and added shrimp at the end.

This is my got to on cold days. But I add shrimp as well to it. Never had any complaints! Easy to make one pot dinner. But don't take my word for it. Try it out yourself. I don't think you will be disappointed. Enjoy. Thanks for sharing this recipe.

I made the recipe almost exactly according to the instructions. My only changes were 1) I used olive oil, 2) I used 12 oz of sausage and added about a half pound of chicken thighs in addition to the 1lb of chicken breast 3) I used cornstarch instead of file powder and 4) used diced tomatoes because I didn't have any crushed. With the tomatoes I simply crushed them by hand in a bowl before adding. The dish came out excellent. I didn't have any issues like others did with the rice being tough or having to add more broth. There was a nice heat, not overly hot. This was a great tasting and easy to make recipe that I will certainly be doing again. Thanks for taking the time to post it.

Very good and easy! I skipped file powder and used butter instead of peanut oil since it was on hand. Turned out fabulously and since I have made it as a double batch since it‚Äôs so good. If you skip the file powder it is still plenty thick.

Very delicious dish. Even my picky son loves it and requests it for special occasions. It's also one of my favorites to cook and to eat. I live at higher altitude, so I have to add a half cup, at least, to the broth for the rice to cook. I also have to cut back on the spices so it's not too hot for my wife and daughter.

I made it exactly like the recipe with one tweak-I put another cup or cup 1/2 of chicken broth. I kept trying grains of rice and kept adding a little broth at a time and letting it cook more. The rice got done though! It‚Äôs very delicious! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è

This was very good! Canola oil was subbed for peanut oil. Ground file was not available so I made a little roux after cooking the veggies. I wanted shrimp too so that went into the pot when adding the andouille and chicken back in. To account for the shrimp - the spices, veggies, rice, crushed tomato and broth were increased proportionally. This went really well with a pan of cornbread! A little kick, but not too much.
Loved this delicious dish. After reading the comments about the rice, I chose to use Jasmine rice,added 1/2 cup more of chicken broth and cooked 10 minutes longer. Came out perfect.
After reading Pamdix comments I omitted the tomato and Worcestershire sauce. We loved it Just enough heat.

I have never had any success with cooking rice with any kind of tomatoes. I have made another recipe for Jambalaya and if you cook the rice with the tomatoes the rice never cooks in 20 min. I like the the crushed tomatoes. I would add tomato paste and diced tomatoes.

Hello ladies and gents, I'm from Gonzales, Louisiana, the Jambalaya Capital of the World. I may be able to help a little with this recipe. First, use any oil you like. Peanut oil is rather expensive. We don't use tomatoes. That's New Orleans style. It's your choice. We don't use Worcestershire sauce nor file. File is for thickening gumbo. We brown our meat pretty well to get the flavor and color of the rice to a medium brown. Your jambalaya should not be watery. It should be just like cooking a pot of rice. If too soupy, keep cooking longer. Instead of using two products to spice it up, your sausage should have enough season with a helping of cajun spice which can be found in any store. You can use chicken stock if you want, but you don't need it. You can use water instead, but the stock kicks it up a notch. I've been cooking jambalaya since I was 17 and I'm 67 now and no one has ever complained. I hope I helped a little.
Love it! My 1st time trying to make Jambalaya. The flavor was amazing!
Loved this dish! Flavor was amazing and easy to make!
Loved it. Perfect flavor.
HOT DANG !!! WE are talking about some kinda awesome good! Absolute must-do. Thank you.

The flavor is on point and is just the right amount of heat. The spices are definitely authentic, but i'd make it 3 cups of chicken stock instead of 2.5. The rice was indeed a little hard despite letting it soak and not touching it. Needs a little more moisture in it to be perfect.
Made it with chicken and sausage. It was delicious!!!

I made this exactly as written (except I put a lid on the pot while the rice was simmering) and it was fantastic! File powder is a great addition, for those of you who didn't use it. I made my own and you could, too. It's just Sassafras leaves. If you happen to be near a Sassafras tree, just pluck 4 or 5 green leaves. I dehydrated mine in my air fryer-130 degrees for literally 10 minutes.
I had most of the ingredients and vaguely followed the recipe but it was perfect. I'm 19 and I've only cooked a proper dinner about 5 times in my life but my boyfriend and I loved it.

Turned out wonderful. I intentionally added more spices to it than the recipe calls for, and it turned out wonderfully. The beauty with this is it is a bit flexible so you can substitute as you go. I don‚Äôt have file powder and I even googled a sub for that, but it wasn‚Äôt necessary. My rice cooked well and I used a cast iron pot with a lid. The family loved it. Definitely saving this to my saved recipes for use again!
Awesome‚Ä¶ I added shrimp and okra along with the sausage and chicken. Very flavorful recipe.
I was pretty skeptical on how this was going to turn out at first. Now having tried it I will definitely make this recipe again. It has so much flavor and texture I absolutely love it.
I've made this twice and substituted the green pepper for a red bell pepper and also added shrimp since it isn't really jambalaya without the shrimp!

I did not use hot pepper sauce and added 2 cans of fire roasted tomatoes for some extra flavor. Then I made more rice than the recipe called for. And didn‚Äôt add file sauce. Very good though. We will be making this more often..

Fabulous recipe. I added too much hot stuff but other than that - wow! I also added more crushed tomato‚Äôs and beef broth. Hubs doesn‚Äôt like chunks of onions or green bell peppers so I pur√©ed and used bacon grease I save to saut√© instead of peanut oil. Added ground sausage as well. I am making this one again!!

Typical‚Ä¶ every time I make a recipe with a thick tomato based sauce, the rice always gets under cooked. I added more liquid and cooked it longer than the recipe called for. Next time I will skip the last step and just cook the rice separate, then put the jambalaya over some perfectly cooked steamed rice.
Made a 5x batch for a party. Worked fine, although it took forever to prep. üòâ Good food. Thanks!

Great easy Recipe One of the things I like about jambalaya is having so many options of what u want to put in or take out Eat in a Bowl on a fajita .. did shrimp ,ground sausage fresh peeled plum tomotoes & pepper but skipped the garlic onion & celery üëç Nice color great flavor maybe add some black beans next time Easy comfort food
Great start but I added shrimp . Old bay seasoning . Thanks
Great recipe. I used shrimp instead of chicken and it turned out great
Made this tonight and loved it. So easy and so delicious! I'll definitely be making it again.
Flavor was good, but after 45 min at a full simmer the rice was still crunchy!! Undercooked rice killed this dish. Everything overcooked trying to cook the rice.

Made it close to exact, except no file powder and added 1lb of shrimp in the last 7 minutes (recommend!). I thought this was delicious!! - but my wife thought it was too spicy - so be careful with the spices - it doesn't need the extra teaspoon of salt - with the Cajun seasoning, Worcestershire sauce and hot sauce, it has plenty of salt already - next time I'll skip the added salt and cut back on the spices, and add my own hot sauce at the table.

I made a few changes to the recipe after reading the reviews. First I used a regular skillet. Second I used olive oil instead of peanut. Third, I added 3 cups of broth. Fourth, I omitted the file powder. My grocery store didn‚Äôt carry it and to be honest I‚Äôve never heard of it. Third I let it cook 35 minutes and last I added shrimp. Adding the extra broth made a big difference. At 35 minutes the rice was 95% done, I think it could have used another 5-10. I don‚Äôt know if it matters but I live in a high elevation (Utah) so maybe that‚Äôs why it takes longer to cook the rice? Anyway, it turned out great! My family loved it!

As a louisiana native this is one of the worst jambalaya recipes i‚Äôve ever seen. The rice should not be cooked like that, there‚Äôs way to much liquid, there‚Äôs no need for the tomatoes, and gumbo fil√© does not belong in jambalaya. Also peanut oil was the worst choice of oil you could‚Äôve used. you need a neutral oil like canola. i can tell whoever made this recipe isn‚Äôt from here. if i could give this zero stars, i would

Turned out fantastic! I followed others‚Äô suggestions‚Äîput in one cup frozen sliced okra at the same time as the onions/veggies, doubled the crusted canned tomatoes, and added cooked cocktail shrimp in the last five minutes‚Ä¶perfect consistency and instant favorite.

Very good. The flavor was amazing! The chicken was so flavorful and tender! YUM! My rice did burn on the bottom of the pot, like black burnt, but I just didn't scratch it off and poured it into a serving dish and it didn't ruin the flavor. Next time I'll just cook the rice separate because my kids love plain rice anyway.

Amazing recipe!! Super easy. I didn't have File powder and omitted the shrimp due to a food allergy. I cooked everthing in the same pot for flavor and made sure to cover and simmer once rice was added so the rice would cook. The family loved it. Will make again!
I added shrimp and my family loved it. I had to use two 14oz cans of tomatoes and additional chicken stock.
Made it ...& Ate it ! ü§§ yummy! I added shrimp last couple of minutes. Tho I didn't use file seasoning could not find it. Will make again! Thanks üòä
No changes
Excellent, we changed the spice a bit but great recipe
Great easy recipe for a family of 4 with plenty of left overs. My 7 year old loves this dish.

Very good and simple to put together. I didn't have any file, but the rice thickened nicely anyway. I used Slap Yo' Momma seasoning which gave it a good kick. I also added shrimp during last 2 minutes. Will definitely make it again.

This has been my basic Jambalaya recipe for years. Have made countless times essentially as written and with most conceivable changes. From stove top to campfire, water bucket to dutch ovens, I've made this recipe! it's easy and most importantly to me (who rarely has all the ingredients as written) you can sub in and out with a lot of latitude and come out great. Spiciness and heat are easily dialed into your tastes and in a pinch, use whatever meat/seafood/poultry you have with any make-do stock and voila.
Made this for my daughter's birthday. Yummy! Everybody ate it up!

The flavor was great, but the like others, the rice did not have enough liquid to cook in, and resulted in some crunch. All in all, a recipe I would make again but I would just go ahead and use the whole can of tomato and cut the rice to 1 cup.
Excellent! Will definitely make again. Made several substitutions based on what I had on hand. Cooked the rice along with the liquid. So good, give this one a try!

So the flavor was awesome, it was pretty easy to come together and cook. I am just super sadly disappointed that my rice never cooked through because now I have a lot of food, but unfortunately I am a texture person and the crunchy rice just ruin the entire recipe. I guess I will try to make the rice separately next time. But it‚Äôs just a whole lot of wasted food. Very sad and very wasteful. I never give bad reviews I always try to stay positive. Thank you. And happy holidays.
The best recipe!
I used beef franks that I had on hand. The jambalaya turned out delicious and satisfied the husband!
Fantastic. Came out great in the instant pot.

I used more cayenne than receipt said and it was on the verge of too spicy. Next time I will use corn instead of celery. Followed the recepie otherwise and it had a lot of flavor. Did not use shrimp but may next time. Made it camping over open fire

This recipe was such a big hit. I was asked to make it for a family gathering and now it‚Äôs kinda my thing. I have a boyfriend who eats plant based though and was able to find enough substitutes to make it for him. It was just as good with meatless pieces as it was with chicken and sausage. The flavors are amazing.

This is easily the best "base" recipe you'll find. 
It is great as is or can be modified.
Add a 1/2 cup of chicken stock at high elevation.

Made this tonight and my husband and son ate almost all of it!! I didn‚Äôt have pepper sauce so I added jalape√±o juice. Also, I added 2 bay leaves. So delicious!!!! Will definitely make, for my boys, again!!

The ingredients mixed well together and my friends who ate it loved it. I subbed turkey smoked sausage for the andouille but everything else was like I remember my mama made it. We are from Louisiana.
MamaBetty
I used leftover grilled chicken and pulled pork and some andouille sausage. It turned out great!

To those who have UNDERCOOKED RICE:

Do this:

Step 3:

Add chicken broth and bring to a boil. THEN add rice folding it in. Fold every minute or so to keep the rice from sticking/burning the bottom.

After 5 - 10 minutes the rice should begin to plump up. When that happens, lower the heat (to low/simmer), and cover. Cook for 25 minutes. Do NOT touch that cover. The steam will help cook the rice.

Oh, also, at step 2, I add okra (frozen diced) to the sautee when cooking the trio.

Source: some random guy from New Orleans posting on some random forum I found at 1 am wondering why my rice was crunchy.

This was delicious! I used shrimp instead of chicken, and added a fresh jalape√±o. Didn‚Äôt have file powder. Next time I‚Äôll make the rice separately and spoon the mixture over it (my husband prefers it that way), but it was yummy with the rice cooked in. Will definitely make again.
Very good! I made the rice separately and used chicken thighs & italian sausage because it's what I had on hand.
Great Jambalaya recipe! I added 1/2 lb uncooked shrimp in the last 7 minutes and it turned out great.

This is a solid recipe for genuine jambalaya. I added some leftover honey baked ham which added one more flavorful meat. I prefer jambalaya without the tomatoes, so I simply omitted them. One last tweak...when everything but the shrimp was in the pot and had come to a boil, I covered it and placed into a 325 degree oven for 40 minutes, added the shrimp and returned it for another 10 minutes. The texture was the best texture I‚Äôve ever made.
super yummy! good spice level!
great recipe! love the flavor I added shrimp after the rice cooked halfway. this is a favorite

I‚Äôm in Minnesota and never had this before. I ordered file from Penzey‚Äôs, but it didn‚Äôt get here in time and my grocery store didn‚Äôt carry it. I followed the recipe exactly except for file, used brown rice and added shrimp. We love spicy and this was a huge hit in my house. I don‚Äôt really know what jambalaya is supposed to look, or taste like, but this will be served often here and next time I‚Äôll have the file. I read most of the reviews, for inspiration. Thanks for a winner recipe!
Loved it! Used chorizo instead of sausage, and will definitely be making this again!
Cooking the rice in the broth like that makes the rice gummy. Not my favorite recipe.
Easy & yummy!

I made this last night and adjusted it to my tastes. I used 1/2 of the spices called for and also substituted sweet red and orange peppers for the bell pepper. I also let everything cook a bit longer than the recipe called for. I also added shrimp when I added the rice. I also used a full 28 Oz can of crushed tomatoes. It came out really well with lots of flavor but not too much heat for me. Thanks so much for the recipe. It was a very good starting point for me.
So good - highly recommend. Everyone can tweak this recipe to their liking but this is such a great foundation.

We really liked this. First time making jambalaya except from a box. Don't judge. Anyway, used Italian sausage and was a little short on rice and no filet powder, but it still turned out well, I think. A little hot for my family, so next time will tame it down just a touch. It did take longer to prep and cook than it says.

Recipe was easy to make except for not being able to find the file powder at my local grocery. I substituted cornstarch & water but did order the file powder from Amazon for the next time I make this. Was yummy & will make it again!
Super easy way to make Jambalaya. Recipe was easy to follow. Put in a bit more hot sauce then suggested
Made it exactly as described. Delicious

I have lived in Baton Rouge for most of my life and a good jambalaya recipe has always eluded me. I took some minor liberties by using deer sausage, deboned chicken thighs and added a chopprd up jalapeno. My wife (from Scott, LA) LOVES IT.
Jammin jambalaya
My family loved it! We decided to have a fun 'Mardi Gras' dinner at our house complete with King Cake and Jambalaya. I had never made it before but found this recipe. It was a huge hit!
I added shrimp as well as sausage and chicken. This dish was amazing!

My picky family LOVES this recipe! I have made it 3 times, and I think I finally perfected it for us. Here's the adjustments I made:
1. I leave out the hot sauce and file powder. It's got plenty of heat for us with just the seasoning and Red Pepper flakes.
2. I use beef Kielbasa instead of anduille, since we already have it and the anduille is a bit hard to find.
3. I use Zatarain's Creole Seasoning instead of Cajun seasoning. Gives it a great smokey flavor with a bit less heat.
4. MOST IMPORTANT! After using 1 1/4 cups of normal, long grain american rice the first two times and being dissapointed that the rice was still crunchy, I switched to using 1 1/2 cups of Jasmine rice (uses less water and cooks faster). It was PERFECTLY DONE and delicious!!
